lead_org: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

unstructured.description: Any subject with National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) very high or high risk adenocarcinoma of the prostate defined as >= T3a, Gleason score >= 8, or prostate-specific antigen (PSA) > 20 who is eligible for RP (open or robotic) with adjuvant EBRT as an initial treatment option.

Any subject with NCCN intermediate risk adenocarcinoma of the prostate defined as T2b-T2c, Gleason score 7, or PSA 10-20 who is eligible for RP (open or robotic) with adjuvant EBRT as an initial treatment option and at least one of the following adverse features present in pre-operative imaging: seminal vesicle invasion (SVI), extracapsular extension (ECE), N1 disease.
Subject must have had a pre-operative magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or must obtain a pre-operative MRI to be eligible for participation in this study.
Ability to understand and the willingness to sign a written informed consent.
Any subject who has undergone prior radiation to the pelvis.
On any investigational drug(s), androgen deprivation therapy or therapeutic device(s) within 30 days preceding screening.
Currently taking immunosuppressants, or with poorly controlled diabetes (hemoglobin [Hb]A1c > 8).
Subjects with prior treatment for prostate cancer (PCa) including brachytherapy (BT), radiation therapy (RT) or hormone therapy.

detail_description:
PRIMARY OBJECTIVES:
I. To determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) for CivaSheet directional Pd103 brachytherapy source (Civasheet) when administered with radical prostatectomy (RP) and adjuvant external beam radiation therapy (EBRT).

SECONDARY OBJECTIVES:
I. To describe the adverse events, toxicity and complication profile associated with Civasheet overall and at each dose when administered with RP with or without adjuvant EBRT.
II. To evaluate the rate of biochemical recurrence (BCR) at 6 months associated with the use of Civasheet when administered with RP and adjuvant EBRT.

OUTLINE: This is a dose-escalation study of CivaSheet.

Participants undergo radical prostatectomy and CivaSheet implantation on day 1. Beginning 6 weeks later, participants whose cancer has spread or was left behind undergo EBRT over 30-60 minutes on Monday to Friday for up to 5 weeks in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable toxicity.

After completion of study treatment, participants are followed up every 6 months for up to 4 years.
official_title: A Phase I Single-Arm Open Label Dose-Escalation Study of CivaSheet with Radical Prostatectomy with or without Adjuvant External Beam Radiation Therapy in Patients with High Risk Prostate Cancer

outcome_measures.name: Acute adverse events assessed using the NCI-CTCAE version 4.0
outcome_measures.description: Radiation Therapy Oncology Group (RTOG) Acute Toxicity Scale will be assessed.

outcome_measures.name: Biochemical recurrence (BCR) defined as a post-prostatectomy serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) > 0.2 ng/ml
outcome_measures.description: Kaplan Meier-Method will be used to estimate BCR overall and for each dose group and separately for those receiving vs. not receiving EBRT.

outcome_measures.name: Erectile preservation
outcome_measures.description: Will be assessed overall and for each dose group once all subjects. Erectile preservation rates (International Index of Erectile Function [IIEF] score [erectile component] > 18) will be assessed. Binary or categorical outcomes will be described with proportion and 95% confidence intervals and continuous measures will be summarized with mean (standard deviation) or median (interquartile range), as appropriate.

outcome_measures.name: Incidence of adverse events assessed according to the NCI CTCAE, version 4.0.
outcome_measures.description: Will describe the adverse events, toxicity and complication profile associated with Civasheet overall and at each dose when administered with radical prostatectomy and EBRT and also separately for those not receiving EBRT.

outcome_measures.name: Late adverse events assessed using the NCI-CTCAE version 4.0
outcome_measures.description: Late Radiation Morbidity scales will be assessed.

outcome_measures.timeframe: Up to 90 days post external beam radiation therapy (EBRT)
outcome_measures.name: Maximum tolerated dose (MTD) defined as the highest dose of the Civasheet not yielding unacceptable toxicity
outcome_measures.description: Specifically, if > 33% of subjects experience dose limiting toxicity (DLT) at any dose level, the dose level below that level will be considered the MTD. DLT is defined as the development of grade 3 or higher (according to the National Cancer Institute's [NCI] Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events [CTCAE] version 4.0) urinary retention, hematuria or rectal bleeding/radiation proctitis within 90 days post EBRT.

outcome_measures.name: Rates for surgical complications
outcome_measures.description: Peri- and post-operative complications associated with surgery will be assessed and graded using the Clavien-Dindo classification of surgical complications.

outcome_measures.name: Total urinary incontinence
outcome_measures.description: Will be assessed overall and for each dose group once all subjects. Continence defined as the use of no pads will also be assessed.

interventions.name: CivaSheet Directional Pd103 Brachytherapy Source

arms.name: Treatment (radical prostatectomy, CivaSheet, EBRT)
arms.description: Participants undergo radical prostatectomy and CivaSheet implantation on day 1. Beginning 6 weeks later, participants whose cancer has spread or was left behind undergo EBRT over 30-60 minutes on Monday to Friday for up to 5 weeks in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable toxicity.

brief_summary: This phase I trial studies the best dose and side effects on Civasheet when given together with surgical removal of prostate and external beam radiation therapy, in treating participants with intermediate or high risk prostate cancer. Civasheet is a flexible sheet that can be implanted on top of (not inside) tissues containing cancer to provide radiation directly to the cancerous areas while shielding and protecting healthy, non-cancerous surrounding organs (such as the bladder and rectum next to the prostate) from receiving the unfavorable side effects of radiation. External bean radiation therapy uses high energy beams to kill tumor cells and shrink tumors. Civasheet and surgery with or without external beam radiation therapy may work better at treating prostate cancer.
brief_title: Civasheet and Surgical Removal of Prostate with or without External Beam Radiation Therapy in Treating Participants with Intermediate or High Risk Prostate Cancer
